article.paragraph: Abdlhamid I,Abdul Hamid IorAbd Al-Hamid I(lang-otaعبد الحميد اول,`Abdl-amd-i evvel;lang-trBirinci Abdülhamit; 20 March 1725 7 April 1789)Some sources state 12 March as his day of birthwas the 27thSultan of the Ottoman Empire, reigning over theOttoman Empirefrom 1774 to 1789.
article.heading: Birth and early life
article.paragraph: He was born inConstantinople, a younger son of SultanAhmed III(reigned 1703–1730) by his consortRabia ermi Sultan. Ahmed III abdicated in favor of his nephewMahmud I, who was succeeded by his brotherOsman III, and Osman by Ahmed's elder sonMustafa III.

As a potential heir to the throne, Abdl Hamid was imprisoned in comfort by his cousins and older brother, as was customary. This lasted until 1767. During this period, he received his early education from his mother Rabia ermi, who taught him history andcalligraphy.
When his brother Mustafa III died, Abdl Hamid succeeded him on 21 January 1774.
article.heading: Reign
article.paragraph: Abdl Hamid's long imprisonment had left him indifferent to state affairs and malleable to the designs of his advisors. Yet he was also very religious and apacifismpacifistby nature. At his accession the financial straits of the treasury were such that the usual donative could not be given to theJanissaryCorps. The new Sultan told the Janissaries "There are no longer gratuities in our treasury, as all of our soldier sons should learn."

Despite the weak condition of the Empire and his pacific inclinations, Turkey was forced to renewRusso-Turkish War (176874)the ongoing warwithRussian EmpireRussiaalmost immediately. This led toBattle of Kozludzhacomplete Turkish defeat at Kozludzhaand the humiliatingTreaty of Kk Kaynarca, signed on 21 July 1774. Turkey ceded territory to Russia, and also the right to intervene on behalf of theEastern Orthodox ChurchOrthodox Christiansin the Empire.

link.part: TheOttoman Armyadvances fromSofia, its largest garrison inRumelia, in the year 1788.

article.paragraph: Abdl Hamid now sought to reform the Empire's armed forces. He enumerated the Janissary corps and tried to renovate it, and also the navy. He established a new artillery corps. He was also credited with the creation of the Imperial Naval Engineering School.

Abdl Hamid tried to strengthen Ottoman rule overOttoman SyriaSyria,Egypt, andIraq.However, slight successes against rebellions in Syria and theMoreacould not compensate for the loss of theCrimean Peninsula, which had become nominally independent in 1774, but was in practice now controlled by Russia.

Russia repeatedly exploited its position as protector of Eastern Christians to interfere in the Ottoman Empire, and explicitly. Finally Turkey declaredRusso-Turkish War (178792)war against Russia in 1787.Austro-Turkish War (178791)Austria soon joined Russia. Turkey held its own in the conflict, at first, but on 6 December 1788,Siege of Ochakov (1788)Ochakov fell to Russia(all of its inhabitants being massacred). It is said that this sad defeat broke Abdl Hamid's spirit, as he died four months later.

In spite of his failures, Abdl Hamid was regarded as the most gracious Ottoman Sultan. He personally directed thefire brigadeduring the Constantinople fire of 1782. He was admired by the people for his religious devotion, and was even called aVeli("saint"). He also outlined a reform policy, supervised the government closely, and worked with statesmen.

In 1789,Tipu Sultan, ruler of theSultanate of Mysoresent an embassy to Abdul Hamid, urgently requesting assistance against theBritish East India Company, and proposed an offensive and defensive alliance. Abdul Hamid informed the Mysori ambassadors that Turkey was still entangled and exhausted from the on-going war with Russia and Austria.
Abdlhamid died on 7 April 1789, at the age of sixty-four, in Constantinople. He was buried in Bahcekapi, a tomb he had built for himself.
He bredArabian horseswith great passion. One breed of Kheylan Arabians was named "Kheylan Abdlhamid" after him.
article.heading: Family
article.paragraph: His wives were: Valide SultanAye Seniyeperver SultanAye Seniyeperver Kadnefendi, Valide SultanNakidil SultanNakidil Kadn Efendi(there have been speculations that she was a cousin ofNapoleon's wifeJosphine de BeauharnaisJosephine;Christine Isom-Verhaaren, "Royal French Women in the Ottoman Sultans' Harem: The Political Uses of Fabricated Accounts from the Sixteenth to the Twenty-first Century",Journal of World History, vol. 17, No. 2, 2006seeAime du Buc de Rivry), Hatice Ruhah Kadnefendi, Hmaah Kadnefendi, Aye Kadnefendi, Binnaz Kadnefendi, Dilpezir Kadnefendi, Mehtabe Kadnefendi, Mislinayab Kadnefendi, Mteber Kadnefendi, Nevres Kadnefendi, Fatma ebsafa Kadnefendi, Mihriban Kadnefendi, Nkhetsez Hanmefendi and Aye Hanmefendi.
His sons were:Mustafa IV(reigned 180708) (by Aye Seniyeperver),Mahmud II(reigned 180839) (byNaksh-i-Dil Haseki), Murad, Nusret, Mehmed, Ahmed, and Sleyman.
His daughters were:Esma Sultana (1778-1848)Esma, Emine, Rabia, Saliha, Alimah, Duruehvar, Fatma, Melikah, Hibetullh, and Zekiye Sultanas.
